abstract: British government announces thousands of gay and bisexual men who were convicted of crimes related to homosexual activity will receive posthumous pardons; law under which pardons will be granted is named after Alan Turing, mathematician who played major role in Britain's military efforts in World War II, but who committed suicide after being convicted on homosexuality charges in 1952; some gay rights activists say law does not go far enough, while others say they deserve apology.
lead_paragraph: The proposed Turing Law, named for the mathematician who was prosecuted in the 1950s, provides for posthumous pardons and allows men who are still alive to apply for pardons.
snippet: The proposed Turing Law, named for the mathematician who was prosecuted in the 1950s, provides for posthumous pardons and allows men who are still alive to apply for pardons....

headline.main: Thousands of Men to Be Pardoned for Gay Sex, Once a Crime in Britain
headline.print_headline: U.K. Bill Pardons Men for Gay Sex
